https://docs.turso.tech//cli/db/create:
# db create

You can create a new database in a specific group using the following command:

```
turso db create
[
database-name
]
```

The `[database-name]` argument is optional. If you don’t provide a name, the Turso team will use the name of your project.

If you have more than one group, you will need to pass the `--group` flag.

## ​Flags

| Flag | Description |
|---|---|
|  `--canary`  | Use database canary build. |
|  `--csv-table-name`  | Name of the table in the csv file. |
|  `--enable-extensions`  | Enables experimental support for SQLite extensions. |
|  `--from-csv`  | Create the database from a csv file. |
|  `--from-db`  | Select another database to copy data from. |
|  `--from-dump`  | Create the database from a local SQLite dump. |
|  `--from-dump-url`  | Create the database from a remote SQLite dump. |
|  `--from-file`  | Create the database from a local SQLite3-compatible file. |
|  `--group`  | Create the database in the specified group. |
|  `-h` , `--help`  | Get help for create. |
|  `--timestamp`  | Set a point in time in the past to copy data from the selected database.

Must be used with the ‘from-db’ flag. Must be in[ RFC3339 ](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc3339)format like ‘2023-09-29T10:16:13-03:00’ |
|  `-w` , `--wait`  | Wait for the database to be ready to receive requests. |


## ​Examples

The examples below outline the most common use cases for the `db create` command.

### ​Create database in a specific group

You can create a new database in a specific group using the `--group` flag:

```
turso db create
[
database-name
]
--group
<
group-name
>
```

### ​Create database from SQLite file

You can create a new Turso database from an existing SQLite file using the `--from-file` flag:

```
turso db create
[
database-name
]
--from-file ./path/to/file.db
```

The file size is limited to 2GB.

### ​Create database from SQLite dump

You can create a new database using the output of `.dump` using the `--from-dump` flag:

```
turso db create
[
database-name
]
--from-dump ./path/to/dump.sql
```

### ​Create database from another existing database

You can create a new Turso database from an existing database using the `--from-db` flag:

```
turso db create
[
database-name
]
--from-db
<
existing-database-name
>
```

### ​Create database from a point in time

You can create a new Turso database from an existing database at a specific point in time using the `--from-db` and `--timestamp` flags:

```
turso db create
[
database-name
]
--from-db
<
existing-database-name
>
--timestamp
2024
-01-01T10:10:10-10:00
```

### ​Create database from a CSV file

You can create a new Turso database from a CSV file using the `--from-csv` flag:

```
turso db create
[
database-name
]
--from-csv ./path/to/file.csv --csv-table-name
<
desired-table-name
>
```

- [ Flags ](https://docs.turso.tech//cli/db/create/#flags)
- [ Examples ](https://docs.turso.tech//cli/db/create/#examples)
- [ Create database in a specific group ](https://docs.turso.tech//cli/db/create/#create-database-in-a-specific-group)
- [ Create database from SQLite file ](https://docs.turso.tech//cli/db/create/#create-database-from-sqlite-file)
- [ Create database from SQLite dump ](https://docs.turso.tech//cli/db/create/#create-database-from-sqlite-dump)
- [ Create database from another existing database ](https://docs.turso.tech//cli/db/create/#create-database-from-another-existing-database)

https://docs.turso.tech//api-reference/d:
# Create Database

Creates a new database in a group for the organization or user.

Bearer authentication header of the form `Bearer <token>` , where `<token>` is your auth token.

The name of the organization or user.

The name of the group where the database should be created. **The group must already exist.** 

The name of the new database. Must contain only lowercase letters, numbers, dashes. No longer than 32 characters.

The name of the existing database when `database` is used as a seed type.

A formatted[ ISO 8601 ](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_8601)recovery point to create a database from. This must be within the last 24 hours, or 30 days on the scaler plan.

The type of seed to be used to create a new database.

The URL returned by[ upload dump ](https://docs.turso.tech/api-reference/databases/upload-dump)can be used with the `dump` seed type.

The maximum size of the database in bytes. Values with units are also accepted, e.g. 1mb, 256mb, 1gb.

```
curl
-L
-X
POST
'https://api.turso.tech/v1/organizations/{organizationName}/databases'
\
-H
'Authorization: Bearer TOKEN'
\
-H
'Content-Type: application/json'
\
-d
'{
      "name": "new-database",
      "group": "default"
  }'
```

```
{
"database"
:
{
"DbId"
:
"0eb771dd-6906-11ee-8553-eaa7715aeaf2"
,
"Hostname"
:
"[databaseName]-[organizationName].turso.io"
,
"Name"
:
"my-db"
}
}
```

#### Path Parameters

The name of the organization or user.

#### Body

The name of the group where the database should be created. **The group must already exist.** 

The name of the new database. Must contain only lowercase letters, numbers, dashes. No longer than 32 characters.

Show child attributes

The name of the existing database when `database` is used as a seed type.

A formatted[ ISO 8601 ](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_8601)recovery point to create a database from. This must be within the last 24 hours, or 30 days on the scaler plan.

The type of seed to be used to create a new database.

`database`

`dump`

The URL returned by[ upload dump ](https://docs.turso.tech/api-reference/databases/upload-dump)can be used with the `dump` seed type.

The maximum size of the database in bytes. Values with units are also accepted, e.g. 1mb, 256mb, 1gb.

#### Response

Show child attributes

The database universal unique identifier (UUID).

The DNS hostname used for client libSQL and HTTP connections.

The database name, **unique** across your organization.

```
curl
-L
-X
POST
'https://api.turso.tech/v1/organizations/{organizationName}/databases'
\
-H
'Authorization: Bearer TOKEN'
\
-H
'Content-Type: application/json'
\
-d
'{
      "name": "new-database",
      "group": "default"
  }'
```

```
{
"database"
:
{
"DbId"
:
"0eb771dd-6906-11ee-8553-eaa7715aeaf2"
,
"Hostname"
:
"[databaseName]-[organizationName].turso.io"
,
"Name"
:
"my-db"
}
}
```
https://docs.turso.tech//cli/db/tokens/c:
# db tokens create

You can create a new token that can be used to connect to one database using the command:

```
turso db tokens create
<
database-name
>
[
flags
]
```

## ​Flags

| Flag | Description |
|---|---|
|  `-e` , `--expiration`  | The expiration time for a token, can be `never` or a value in days, e.g. `7d` . |
|  `-r` , `--read-only`  | Restrict the token to read only access. |


## ​Examples

The examples below outline the most common use cases for the `db tokens create` command.

### ​Create a token with read only access

You can create a token with read only access to a database using the following command:

```
turso db tokens create
<
database-name
>
--read-only
```

### ​Create a token with a specific expiration time

You can create a token with a specific expiration time using the following command:

```
turso db tokens create
<
database-name
>
--expiration
7d3h2m1s
```

- [ Examples ](https://docs.turso.tech//cli/db/tokens/create/#examples)

# group wakeup

Users of the free personal plan can wakeup inactive databases by running the following command:

```
turso group update
<
group-name
>
[
flags
]
```

Databases go to sleep after 10 days of inactivity.

# Usage & Billing

For the Starter and Scaler plans, Turso usage is limited monthly based on the following usage observations during each calendar month:

- Number of table[ rows read ](https://docs.turso.tech/help/usage-and-billing#rows-read)
- Number of table[ rows written ](https://docs.turso.tech/help/usage-and-billing#rows-written)
- Amount of[ total storage ](https://docs.turso.tech/help/usage-and-billing#total-storage)


In billing plans that include monthly quotas for row reads, row writes, and total storage, any query that exceeds these limits will result in a failure, indicated by the `BLOCKED` error code.

## ​Rows Read

In SQLite, the term “row read” actually refers to a “row scan” during statement execution. Key points to remember with the Turso CLI metrics:

- **SQL Queries:** May scan more rows than returned.
- **SQL Updates:** Each updated row results in at least one row scan.


### ​Aggregate Function Impact

Using functions like `count` , `avg` , `min` , `max` , and `sum` results in a row scan for every row considered in the aggregation.

Improve query efficiency by storing aggregate values in a separate table and
updating it transactionally with the base table changes.

### ​Full Table Scans

Queries lacking index support perform a full table scan, incurring a row scan for each table row.

Seek strategies to minimize costly table scans.

### ​Complex Query Costs

Table joins, subqueries, and compound queries incur a row scan for each considered row from all involved tables.

### ​Update Mechanics

SQL updates read (and write) each row they modify. Absent an index for row filtering, a full table scan is performed, adding a read for each table row, plus a write for each updated row.

### ​ALTER TABLE and Row Reads

`ALTER TABLE`

 `ALTER TABLE` operations, especially those rewriting row contents, necessitate a full table scan, incurring a read for each table row. However, not all `ALTER TABLE` actions, like `DROP COLUMN` , lead to full scans. Be mindful of potential row writes as well.

### ​Indexing Costs

Adding an index to an existing table triggers a full table scan, with one read per existing row.

### ​SQLite System Tables

Internal SQLite tables, like `dbstat` and those with `sqlite_` prefix, don’t incur row reads in queries.

### ​Zero-Read Commands

Commands not involving row reads/writes, like `select 1` , default to one row read.

## ​Rows Written

In SQLite, a “row written” encompasses both the insertion of a new row and the update of an existing row.

### ​ALTER TABLE and Row Writes

`ALTER TABLE`

 `ALTER TABLE` operations can result in a row write for each existing row, especially if the row data is altered during the process. It’s important to understand how different types of `ALTER TABLE` statements impact row writes.

### ​Implications of Aborted Transactions

Even if a transaction is not committed, any row that was inserted or updated during the transaction incurs a row write. This underscores the importance of transaction management in controlling database writes.

 `ALTER TABLE` actions may also lead to row reads, adding another layer to consider when modifying table structures.

## ​Total Storage

SQLite utilizes the virtual table[ dbstat ](https://www.sqlite.org/dbstat.html)to calculate the total space used by all tables and indexes. The base unit for this measurement is a database file page, which is 4KB.

In SQLite, the `VACUUM` command is a common tool for optimizing storage by compacting the database. However, it’s important to note that this command is currently disabled in Turso. Future updates may introduce options for developers to efficiently manage and reduce the total storage footprint of their databases.

## ​Reducing Usage

### ​Query Execution

Familiarizing yourself with the[ SQLite query planner ](https://www.sqlite.org/queryplanner.html)can significantly enhance your understanding of how your queries are executed. This knowledge is pivotal in optimizing query efficiency.

### ​Query Planning

Utilize the[ EXPLAIN QUERY PLAN ](https://www.sqlite.org/eqp.html)statement to gain insights into your query’s execution plan. This tool is invaluable for identifying whether your query is performing a full table scan and if it’s leveraging the most efficient index to reduce unnecessary reads.

### ​Indexing

Ensure that your queries are designed to take advantage of indexes for row filtering. The absence of suitable indexes forces SQLite to resort to full table scans, incrementally increasing the read count by one for each row in the table. Efficient indexing is key to minimizing this overhead.

Incorporating necessary indexes at the table creation stage is a best practice. Adding indexes to tables that already contain rows triggers a full table scan, with each existing row necessitating one read. Proactive index management is crucial for maintaining optimal database performance.

# Welcome to Turso

Turso is a SQLite-compatible database built on[ libSQL ](https://docs.turso.tech/libsql), the Open Contribution fork of SQLite. It enables scaling to hundreds of thousands of databases per organization and supports replication to any location, including your own servers, for microsecond-latency access.

## ​New to Turso?

Start using Turso with your existing SQLite database, or create one with Turso.

## Quickstart

Get started with Turso to create and integrate your first database.

## ​Start building

Learn how to manage, distribute and integrate your databases with the CLI, API and SDKs.

## Turso CLI

Manage groups, databases, and API tokens with the Turso CLI.

## Turso Platform API

Manage groups, databases, and API tokens with the Turso API.

## SDKs

Integrate Turso into your application with one of our libSQL drivers.

## Tutorials

Learn how to work with Turso and your favorite language or framework.

## ​Join the community

Join the Turso community to ask questions, discuss best practices, and share tips.

## Discord

## GitHub

## Twitter / X

- [ New to Turso? ](https://docs.turso.tech/#rows-read/#new-to-turso)
- [ Start building ](https://docs.turso.tech/#rows-read/#start-building)
- [ Join the community ](https://docs.turso.tech/#rows-read/#join-the-community)

# Welcome to Turso

Turso is a SQLite-compatible database built on[ libSQL ](https://docs.turso.tech/libsql), the Open Contribution fork of SQLite. It enables scaling to hundreds of thousands of databases per organization and supports replication to any location, including your own servers, for microsecond-latency access.

## ​New to Turso?

Start using Turso with your existing SQLite database, or create one with Turso.

## Quickstart

Get started with Turso to create and integrate your first database.

## ​Start building

Learn how to manage, distribute and integrate your databases with the CLI, API and SDKs.

## Turso CLI

Manage groups, databases, and API tokens with the Turso CLI.

## Turso Platform API

Manage groups, databases, and API tokens with the Turso API.

## SDKs

Integrate Turso into your application with one of our libSQL drivers.

## Tutorials

Learn how to work with Turso and your favorite language or framework.

Join the Turso community to ask questions, discuss best practices, and share tips.

https://docs.turso.tech//cli/auth/login:
# auth login

To authenticate the Turso CLI with your account, run the following command:

`turso auth login`
https://docs.turso.tech//cli/auth/logout:
# auth logout

To logout of the Turso CLI, run the following command:

```
turso auth
logout
```
https://docs.turso.tech//cli/auth/signup:
# auth signup

To sign up for a new Turso account using the CLI, run the following command:

`turso auth signup`
https://docs.turso.tech//cli/auth/token:
# auth token

You can obtain your current API token that is used to authenticate with the Turso Platform API by running the following command:

`turso auth token`
https://docs.turso.tech//cli/auth/whoami:
# auth whoami

You can obtain the username for the currently logged in user by running the following command:

```
turso auth
whoami
```
https://docs.turso.tech//cli/contact/boo:
# contact bookmeeting

You can book a meeting with the Turso team to discuss your project and requirements using the following command:

`turso contact bookmeeting`

You will be redirected to a webpage where you can select a date and time for the meeting.
https://docs.turso.tech//cli/contact/fee:
# contact feedback

You can send feedback to the Turso team by using the following command:

`turso contact feedback`
https://docs.turso.tech//cli/auth/api-to:
# auth api-tokens revoke

To revoke an API token for the current organization, run the following command:

```
turso auth api-tokens revoke
<
api-token-name
>
```
https://docs.turso.tech//cli/db/list:
# db list

You can obtain a list of all databases for the current user or organization by running the following command:

`turso db list`

The URL returned by this command is the one you should use to connect to the database. Turso automatically routes to the closest replica if you have any.
https://docs.turso.tech//cli/db/show:
# db show

You can obtain details about the database, including the name, ID, version, group, size and locations. You can also obtain the different URLs for the database using the following command:

```
turso db show
<
database-name
>
[
flags
]
```

## ​Flags

| Flag | Description |
|---|---|
|  `--url`  | Show URL for the database HTTP API. |
|  `--http-url`  | Show HTTP URL for the database HTTP API. |
|  `--instance-urls`  | Show individual instance URLS for primary and replica instances. |


- [ Flags ](https://docs.turso.tech//cli/db/show/#flags)
https://docs.turso.tech//cli/db/destroy:
# db destroy

You can destroy a database, including any replicas by using the following command:

```
turso db destroy
<
database-name
>
[
flags
]
```

## ​Flags

| Flag | Description |
|---|---|
|  `-y` , `--yes`  | Confirms the destruction the database. |


- [ Flags ](https://docs.turso.tech//cli/db/destroy/#flags)
https://docs.turso.tech//cli/db/inspect:
# db inspect

You can inspect the usage of a database, including the total space used, rows read and written with the following command:

```
turso db inspect
<
database-name
>
```

## ​Flags

| Flag | Description |
|---|---|
|  `--queries`  | Show database query statistics. |
|  `--verbose`  | Show detailed information, including the location and instance type. |


## ​Examples

### ​Top Queries

You can fetch the most executed, resource-intensive SQL statements that have been run against your database using the Turso CLI:

```
turso db inspect
<
database-name
>
--queries
```

- [ Flags ](https://docs.turso.tech//cli/db/inspect/#flags)
- [ Examples ](https://docs.turso.tech//cli/db/inspect/#examples)
- [ Top Queries ](https://docs.turso.tech//cli/db/inspect/#top-queries)
https://docs.turso.tech//cli/db/shell:
# db shell

You can connect directly to a Turso database by using the following command:

```
turso db shell
<
database-name
|
replica-url
>
[
sql
]
[
flags
]
```

## ​Flags

| Flag | Description |
|---|---|
|  `--instance`  | Connect to the specified database instance. |
|  `---location nrt`  | Connect to the database at the specified location. |
|  `--proxy`  | The proxy to use when connecting to the database. |


## ​Examples

### ​Execute SQL

You can execute SQL directly against a database using the shell:

```
turso db shell
<
database-name
>
"SELECT * FROM users"
```

### ​Database dump

You can dump the contents of a Turso dataase using the following command:

```
turso db shell
<
database-name
>
.dump
>
dump.sql
```

The `.dump` can be used to rebuild a database and doesn’t contain any libSQL or SQLite internal tables.

### ​Load from dump

You can load a dump file into a new database using the following command:

```
turso db shell
<
database-name
>
<
dump.sql
```

### ​Shell with libSQL server

If you’re using `turso dev` locally, you can use the shell by providing the URL to your database:

`turso db shell http://127.0.0.1:8080`

- [ Flags ](https://docs.turso.tech//cli/db/shell/#flags)
- [ Examples ](https://docs.turso.tech//cli/db/shell/#examples)
- [ Execute SQL ](https://docs.turso.tech//cli/db/shell/#execute-sql)
- [ Database dump ](https://docs.turso.tech//cli/db/shell/#database-dump)
- [ Load from dump ](https://docs.turso.tech//cli/db/shell/#load-from-dump)
- [ Shell with libSQL server ](https://docs.turso.tech//cli/db/shell/#shell-with-libsql-server)
https://docs.turso.tech//cli/group/list:
# group list

You can obtain a list of all groups, including the primary and replica locations using the following command:

`turso group list`
https://docs.turso.tech//cli/group/creat:
# group create

You can create a new group of databases. Groups belong to a primary region and can be replicated to other regions.

```
turso group create
<
group-name
>
[
flags
]
```

Turso will automatically detect the closest region and use that as the primary region. You can override this by specifying the `--location` flag.

## ​Flags

| Flag | Description |
|---|---|
|  `--canary`  | Use database canary build. |
|  `--location`  | Create the group in the specified priary location using a three-digit code. |
|  `-w` , `--wait`  | Wait for group to be ready before exiting. |


- [ Flags ](https://docs.turso.tech//cli/group/create/#flags)
https://docs.turso.tech//cli/group/updat:
# group update

You can update the group, including all databases the following command:

```
turso group update
<
group-name
>
[
flags
]
```

## ​Flags

| Flag | Description |
|---|---|
|  `--extensions string`  | Enable extensions by passing `all` or `none` . |
|  `--version string`  | Specify the version of the group to update to. Values include `latest` or `canary` . |
|  `-y` , `--yes`  | Skip confirmation prompt and confirm. |


- [ Flags ](https://docs.turso.tech//cli/group/update/#flags)
https://docs.turso.tech//cli/group/destr:
# group destroy

You can destroy a group and all of its databases using the following command:

```
turso group destroy
<
group-name
>
[
flags
]
```

## ​Flags

| Flag | Description |
|---|---|
|  `-y` , `--yes`  | Confirms destroying the group, with all locations and databases. |


- [ Flags ](https://docs.turso.tech//cli/group/destroy/#flags)
https://docs.turso.tech//cli/group/trans:
# group transfer

You can transfer a group (including its databases) to an organization you’re an admin or owner of using the following command:

```
turso group transfer
<
group-name
>
<
organization-name
>
[
flags
]
```

Existing database URL and tokens will continue to work, but should update your application to use the new URL and token as soon as possible.

## ​Flags

| Flag | Description |
|---|---|
|  `-y` , `--yes`  | Confirms the transfer to a new organization. |


- [ Flags ](https://docs.turso.tech//cli/group/transfer/#flags)
https://docs.turso.tech//cli/org/switch:
# org switch

To switch the current active organization for the CLI, use the following command:

```
turso org switch
<
organization-slug
>
```
https://docs.turso.tech//cli/org/list:
# org list

To list organizations of which you are the owner or a member, run the following command:

`turso org list`
https://docs.turso.tech//cli/org/create:
# org create

To create a new organization that you own, run the following command:

```
turso org create
<
name
>
```

You will be asked to add a payment method and subscribe to the Scaler plan to successfully create a new organization.
https://docs.turso.tech//cli/org/billing:
# org billing

To open the billing portal for your organization:

`turso org billing`
https://docs.turso.tech//cli/plan/show:
# plan show

You can show the current plan usage and limits with the command:

`turso plan show`
https://docs.turso.tech//cli/plan/select:
# plan select

You can switch your current plan at any time using the command:

```
turso plan
select
```

You will need to add your credit card details to your account before you can upgrade to a paid plan.[ Learn more ](https://turso.tech/pricing)about pricing.
https://docs.turso.tech//cli/plan/upgrad:
# plan upgrade

You can upgrade your account to a paid plan at any time using the command:

`turso plan upgrade`

You will need to add your credit card details to your account before you can upgrade to a paid plan.
https://docs.turso.tech//cli/org/members:
# org members rm

To remove a member from the current organization, use the following command:

```
turso org members
rm
<
username
>
```
https://docs.turso.tech//sdk/http:
# Turso Quickstart (HTTP)

Get started with Turso over HTTP in a few simple steps.

In this HTTP quickstart we will learn how to:

- Obtain HTTP URL for a Turso database
- Create a database auth token
- Connect to a remote Turso database
- Execute a SQL using the[ Hrana over HTTP ](https://github.com/tursodatabase/libsql/blob/main/docs/HTTP_V2_SPEC.md)protocol


Create HTTP Database URL

Using the[ Turso CLI ](https://docs.turso.tech/cli)or[ Platform API ](https://docs.turso.tech/api-reference), fetch your database URL:

```
turso db show
<
database-name
>
--http-url
```

Append `/v2/pipeline` to the URL and continue.

Create Database Auth Token

Using the Turso CLI or Platform API, create a new auth token for your database:

```
turso db tokens create
<
database-name
>
```

Create JSON Request Payload

We’ll be sending the query using JSON, so let’s create a JSON payload that executes a SQL statement and closes the connection immediately:

```
{
"requests"
:
[
{
"type"
:
"execute"
,
"stmt"
:
{
"sql"
:
"SELECT * FROM users"
}
}
,
{
"type"
:
"close"
}
]
}
```

Make sure to update the `stmt.sql` to select from a table you already have.

Execute HTTP Request

Depending on your language, you can use a HTTP client library to send the request to the URL you created as well as the `Authorization` header set to the token you created, and the request body as JSON with your SQL statement.

You must append to the Base URL the actual pipeline URL that accepts requests — `/v2/pipeline` .

```
const
url
=
"https://[databaseName]-[organizationName].turso.io/v2/pipeline"
;
const
authToken
=
"..."
;
fetch
(
url
,
{
method
:
"POST"
,
headers
:
{
Authorization
:
` Bearer  ${ authToken } `
,
"Content-Type"
:
"application/json"
,
}
,
body
:
JSON
.
stringify
(
{
requests
:
[
{
type
:
"execute"
,
stmt
:
{
sql
:
"SELECT * FROM users"
}
}
,
{
type
:
"close"
}
,
]
,
}
)
,
}
)
.
then
(
(
res
)
=>
res
.
json
(
)
)
.
then
(
(
data
)
=>
console
.
log
(
data
)
)
.
catch
(
(
err
)
=>
console
.
log
(
err
)
)
;
```

Response

The response will be a JSON object with a `results` array containing the results of your query that looks something like this:

```
{
"baton"
:
null
,
"base_url"
:
null
,
"results"
:
[
{
"type"
:
"ok"
,
"response"
:
{
"type"
:
"execute"
,
"result"
:
{
"cols"
:
[
]
,
"rows"
:
[
]
,
"affected_row_count"
:
0
,
"last_insert_rowid"
:
null
,
"replication_index"
:
"1"
}
}
}
,
{
"type"
:
"ok"
,
"response"
:
{
"type"
:
"close"
}
}
]
}
```

Turso is a SQLite-compatible database built on[ libSQL ](https://docs.turso.tech/libsql), the Open Contribution fork of SQLite. It enables scaling to hundreds of thousands of databases per organization and supports replication to any location, including your own servers, for microsecond-latency access.

# Retrieve Database

Returns a database belonging to the organization or user.

Bearer authentication header of the form `Bearer <token>` , where `<token>` is your auth token.

The name of the organization or user.

The name of the database.

```
curl
-L
'https://api.turso.tech/v1/organizations/{organizationName}/databases/{databaseName}'
\
-H
'Authorization: Bearer TOKEN'
```

```
{
"database"
:
{
"DbId"
:
"0eb771dd-6906-11ee-8553-eaa7715aeaf2"
,
"Hostname"
:
"[databaseName]-[organizationName].turso.io"
,
"Name"
:
"my-db"
,
"group"
:
"default"
,
"primaryRegion"
:
"lhr"
,
"regions"
:
[
"lhr"
,
"bos"
,
"nrt"
]
,
"type"
:
"logical"
,
"version"
:
"0.21.9"
}
}
```

#### Path Parameters

The name of the organization or user.

The name of the database.

#### Response

Show child attributes

The database universal unique identifier (UUID).

The DNS hostname used for client libSQL and HTTP connections.

The database name, **unique** across your organization.

The name of the group the database belongs to.

The primary region location code the group the database belongs to.

A list of regions for the group the database belongs to.

The string representing the object type.

The current libSQL version the database is running.

```
curl
-L
'https://api.turso.tech/v1/organizations/{organizationName}/databases/{databaseName}'

# Prisma + Turso

Configure Prisma to work with your Turso database

Image: [ Prisma banner ](https://mintlify.s3-us-west-1.amazonaws.com/turso/images/guides/prisma-banner.png)

## ​Prerequisites

Before you start, make sure you:

- [ Install the Turso CLI ](https://docs.turso.tech/cli/installation)
- [ Sign up or login to Turso ](https://docs.turso.tech/cli/authentication#signup)
- Prisma versions 5.4.2 and later


Install the libSQL SDK and its Prisma driver

```
npm
install
@libsql/client @prisma/adapter-libsql
```

Configure database credentials

Get the database URL:

```
turso db show
--url
<
database-name
>
```

Get the database authentication token:

```
turso db tokens create
<
database-name
>
```

Assign credentials to the environment variables inside `.env.local` :

```
TURSO_DATABASE_URL
=
"..."
TURSO_AUTH_TOKEN
=
"..."
```

Enable the `driverAdapters` Preview feature flag:

```
generator client
{
provider
=
"prisma-client-js"
previewFeatures
=
[
"driverAdapters"
]
}
```

Generate Prisma client

`npx prisma generate`

Update your Prisma Client Instance

```
import
{
PrismaClient
}
from
"@prisma/client"
;
import
{
PrismaLibSQL
}
from
"@prisma/adapter-libsql"
;
import
{
createClient
}
from
"@libsql/client"
;
const
libsql
=
createClient
(
{
url
:
process
.
env
.
TURSO_DATABASE_URL
,
authToken
:
process
.
env
.
TURSO_AUTH_TOKEN
,
}
)
;
const
adapter
=
new
PrismaLibSQL
(
libsql
)
;
const
prisma
=
new
PrismaClient
(
{
adapter
}
)
;
```

Query your database

```
const
response
=
await
prisma
.
table_name
.
findMany
(
)
;
```

- [ Prerequisites ](https://docs.turso.tech//sdk/ts/orm/prisma/#prerequisites)

# Tauri + Turso

Set up Turso in your Tauri project in minutes

Image: [ Tauri banner ](https://mintlify.s3-us-west-1.amazonaws.com/turso/images/guides/tauri-banner.png)

## ​Prerequisites

Before you start, make sure you:

- [ Install the Turso CLI ](https://docs.turso.tech/cli/installation)
- [ Sign up or login to Turso ](https://docs.turso.tech/cli/authentication#signup)
- Have a Tauri app —[ learn more ](https://tauri.app/v1/guides/getting-started/setup)


Add the following crates to the Tauri project's dependencies

```
[
dependencies
]
serde_json
=
"1.0"
serde
=
{
version
=
"1.0"
,
features
=
[
"derive"
]
}
reqwest
=
{
version
=
"0.11.22"
,
features
=
[
"json"
,
"blocking"
]
}
dotenvy
=
"0.15.7"
tokio
=
{
version
=
"1"
,
features
=
[
"full"
]
}
libsql
=
{
git
=
"https://github.com/tursodatabase/libsql"
}
tracing-subscriber
=
"0.3"
tracing
=
"0.1.40"
[
patch.crates-io
]
sqlite3-parser
=
{
git
=
"https://github.com/LucioFranco/lemon-rs"
}
```

Fetch Rust dependencies inside the `src-tauri` directory.

```
cargo
fetch
```

Configure database credentials

Get the database URL.

```
turso db show
--url
<
database-name
>
```

Get the database authentication token.

```
turso db tokens create
<
database-name
>
```

Assign acquired credentials to the environment variables inside `src-tauri/.env` .

```
TURSO_SYNC_URL
=
"..."
TURSO_AUTH_TOKEN
=
"..."
DB_PATH
=
./my-data.db
# embedded replica
```

Execute SQL

```

dotenvy ::
dotenv
;

libsql ::
{

Database

.

pass

id
:

[

bar
:

mapped_column

100
)

self

-

str

# Welcome to Turso

Turso is a SQLite-compatible database built on[ libSQL ](https://docs.turso.tech/libsql), the Open Contribution fork of SQLite. It enables scaling to hundreds of thousands of databases per organization and supports replication to any location, including your own servers, for microsecond-latency access.

## ​New to Turso?

# Flutter + Turso

Set up Turso in your Flutter project in minutes

Image: [ Flutter banner ](https://mintlify.s3-us-west-1.amazonaws.com/turso/images/guides/flutter-banner.png)

## ​Prerequisites

Before you start, make sure you:

- [ Install the Turso CLI ](https://docs.turso.tech/cli/installation)
- [ Sign up or login to Turso ](https://docs.turso.tech/cli/authentication#signup)
- Have a Flutter app —[ learn more ](https://docs.flutter.dev/get-started/codelab)


Add HTTP Package

```
dart pub
add
http
```

Configure database credentials

Get the database URL.

```
turso db show
--url
<
database-name
>
```

Get the database authentication token.

```
turso db tokens create
<
database-name
>
```

Pass the credentials to the flutter app by using the `--dart-define` flags:

```
flutter run
--debug
\
--dart-define
=
TURSO_URL
=
"..."
\
--dart-define
=
TURSO_AUTH_TOKEN
=
"..."
```

Make sure that the `TURSO_URL` passed above should be modified to use the `https` protocol instead of `libsql` . (e.g “https://[db-name].turso.io”)

Execute SQL

```
import
'package:http/http.dart'
as
http
;
const
String
tursoDbUrl
=
String
.
fromEnvironment
(
"TURSO_URL"
,
defaultValue
:
""
)
;
const
String
tursoAuthToken
=
String
.
fromEnvironment
(
"TURSO_AUTH_TOKEN"
,
defaultValue
:
""
)
;
late
Future
< List < T > >
itemResults
;
Future
< List < T > >
getItems
(
)
async
{
final
response
=
await
http
.
post
(
Uri
.
parse
(
tursoDbUrl
)
,
headers
:
{
HttpHeaders
.
authorizationHeader
:
"Bearer  $ tursoAuthToken "
,
HttpHeaders
.
acceptHeader
:
"application/json"
}
,
body
:
json
.
encode
(
{
"statements"
:
[
"select * from table_name"
]
}
)
)
;
var
itemList
=
List
< T >
.
from
(
jsonDecode
(
response
.
body
)
[
0
]
[
"results"
]
[
"rows"
]
.
map
(
(
dynamic
item
)
=
>
item
[
0
]
)
)
;
return
itemList
;
}
itemResults
=
getItems
(
)
;
```

# List API Tokens

Returns a list of API tokens belonging to a user.

Bearer authentication header of the form `Bearer <token>` , where `<token>` is your auth token.

```
curl
-L
https://api.turso.tech/v1/auth/api-tokens
\
-H
'Authorization: Bearer TOKEN'
```

```
{
"tokens"
:
[
{
"id"
:
"clGFZ4STEe6fljpFzIum8A"
,
"name"
:
"my-token"
}
]
}
```

#### Response

Show child attributes

The ID generated by Turso for the API Token.

The name given to the API Token.

```
curl
-L
https://api.turso.tech/v1/auth/api-tokens
\
-H
'Authorization: Bearer TOKEN'
```

```
{
"tokens"
:
[
{
"id"
:
"clGFZ4STEe6fljpFzIum8A"
,
"name"
:
"my-token"
}
]
}
```
https://docs.turso.tech//api-reference/g:
# List Groups

Returns a list of groups belonging to the organization or user.

Bearer authentication header of the form `Bearer <token>` , where `<token>` is your auth token.

The name of the organization or user.

```
curl
-L
https://api.turso.tech/v1/organizations/
{
organizationName
}
/groups
\
-H
'Authorization: Bearer TOKEN'
```

```
{
"groups"
:
[
{
"archived"
:
true
,
"locations"
:
[
"lhr"
,
"ams"
,
"bos"
]
,
"name"
:
"default"
,
"primary"
:
"lhr"
,
"uuid"
:
"0a28102d-6906-11ee-8553-eaa7715aeaf2"
}
]
}
```

#### Path Parameters

The name of the organization or user.

#### Response

Show child attributes

Groups on the free tier go to sleep after some inactivity.

An array of location keys the group is located.

The group name, unique across your organization.

The primary location key.

The group universal unique identifier (UUID).

```
curl
-L
https://api.turso.tech/v1/organizations/
{
organizationName
}
/groups
\
-H
'Authorization: Bearer TOKEN'
```

```
{
"groups"
:
[
{
"archived"
:
true
,
"locations"
:
[
"lhr"
,
"ams"
,
"bos"
]
,
"name"
:
"default"
,
"primary"
:
"lhr"
,
"uuid"
:
"0a28102d-6906-11ee-8553-eaa7715aeaf2"
}
]
}
```

# Create Group

Creates a new group for the organization or user.

Bearer authentication header of the form `Bearer <token>` , where `<token>` is your auth token.

The name of the organization or user.

The extensions to enable for new databases created in this group.

The location key for the new group.

The name of the new group.

```
curl
-L
-X
POST
'https://api.turso.tech/v1/organizations/{organizationName}/groups'
\
-H
'Authorization: Bearer TOKEN'
\
-H
'Content-Type: application/json'
\
-d
'{
    "name": "new-group",
    "location": "lhr"
}'
```

```
{
"group"
:
{
"archived"
:
true
,
"locations"
:
[
"lhr"
,
"ams"
,
"bos"
]
,
"name"
:
"default"
,
"primary"
:
"lhr"
,
"uuid"
:
"0a28102d-6906-11ee-8553-eaa7715aeaf2"
}
}
```

#### Path Parameters

The name of the organization or user.

#### Body

The extensions to enable for new databases created in this group.

`all`

The location key for the new group.

The name of the new group.

Show child attributes

# Transfer Group

Transfer a group to another organization that you own or a member of.

Bearer authentication header of the form `Bearer <token>` , where `<token>` is your auth token.

The name of the organization or user.

The name of the group.

The name of the organization to transfer the group to.

```
curl
-L
-X
POST
'https://api.turso.tech/v1/organizations/{organizationName}/groups/{groupName}/transfer'
\
-H
'Authorization: Bearer TOKEN'
\
-d
'{
    "organization": "new-organization-name"
}'
```

```
{
"archived"
:
true
,
"locations"
:
[
"lhr"
,
"ams"
,
"bos"
]
,
"name"
:
"default"
,
"primary"
:
"lhr"
,
"uuid"
:
"0a28102d-6906-11ee-8553-eaa7715aeaf2"
}
```

You can only transfer groups to organizations you own or are an admin.

Existing database URL and tokens will continue to work, but should update your application to use the new URL and token as soon as possible.

The name of the organization or user.

The name of the group.

#### Body

The name of the organization to transfer the group to.

# Update Databases in a Group

Updates all databases in the grooup to the latest libSQL version.

Bearer authentication header of the form `Bearer <token>` , where `<token>` is your auth token.

The name of the organization or user.

The name of the group.

```
curl
-L
-X
POST
'https://api.turso.tech/v1/organizations/{organizationName}/groups/{groupName}/update'
\
-H
'Authorization: Bearer TOKEN'
```

`This response has no body data.`

This operation causes some amount of downtime to occur during the update process. The version of libSQL server is taken from the latest built docker image.

#### Path Parameters

The name of the organization or user.

The name of the group.

```
curl
-L
-X
POST
'https://api.turso.tech/v1/organizations/{organizationName}/groups/{groupName}/update'
\
-H
'Authorization: Bearer TOKEN'
```

`This response has no body data.`

# Create Group Auth Token

Generates an authorization token for the specified group.

Bearer authentication header of the form `Bearer <token>` , where `<token>` is your auth token.

The name of the organization or user.

The name of the group.

Expiration time for the token (e.g., 2w1d30m).

Authorization level for the token (full-access or read-only).

```
curl
-L
-X
POST
'https://api.turso.tech/v1/organizations/{organizationName}/groups/{groupName}/auth/tokens?expiration=2w&authorization=full-access'
\
-H
'Authorization: Bearer TOKEN'
```

```
{
"jwt"
:
"TOKEN"
}
```

Tokens cannot be retrieved once created, and cannot be revoked individually.

#### Path Parameters

The name of the organization or user.

The name of the group.

#### Query Parameters

Expiration time for the token (e.g., 2w1d30m).

Authorization level for the token (full-access or read-only).

`full-access`

`read-only`

#### Response

The generated authorization token (JWT).

```
curl
-L
-X
POST
'https://api.turso.tech/v1/organizations/{organizationName}/groups/{groupName}/auth/tokens?expiration=2w&authorization=full-access'
\
-H
'Authorization: Bearer TOKEN'
```

```
{
"jwt"
:
"TOKEN"
}
```

# Upload Dump

Upload a SQL dump to be used when[ creating a new database ](https://docs.turso.tech/api-reference/databases/create)from seed.

Bearer authentication header of the form `Bearer <token>` , where `<token>` is your auth token.

Database dump file.

```
curl
-L
-X
POST
'https://api.turso.tech/v1/organizations/{organizationName}/databases/dumps'
\
-H
'Authorization: Bearer TOKEN'
\
-F
'file=@"~/Downloads/dump.sql"'
```

```
{
"dump_url"
:
"<string>"
}
```

#### Body

Database dump file.

#### Response

URL of the uploaded database dump.

```
curl
-L
-X
POST
'https://api.turso.tech/v1/organizations/{organizationName}/databases/dumps'
\
-H
'Authorization: Bearer TOKEN'
\
-F
'file=@"~/Downloads/dump.sql"'
```

```
{
"dump_url"
:
"<string>"
}
```

# Retrieve Database Usage

Fetch activity usage for a database in a given time period.

Bearer authentication header of the form `Bearer <token>` , where `<token>` is your auth token.

The name of the organization or user.

The name of the database.

The datetime to retrieve usage **from** in[ ISO 8601 ](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_8601)format. Defaults to the current calendar month if not provided. Example: `2023-01-01T00:00:00Z` 

The datetime to retrieve usage **to** in[ ISO 8601 ](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_8601)format. Defaults to the current calendar month if not provided. Example: `2023-02-01T00:00:00Z`

# Retrieve Database Stats

Fetch the top queries of a database, including the count of rows read and written.

Bearer authentication header of the form `Bearer <token>` , where `<token>` is your auth token.

The name of the organization or user.

The name of the database.

```
curl
-L
-X
GET
'https://api.turso.tech/v1/organizations/{organizationName}/databases/{databaseName}/stats'
\
-H
'Authorization: Bearer TOKEN'
```

```
{
"top_queries"
:
[
{
"query"
:
"SELECT COUNT(*), CustomerID FROM Orders GROUP BY CustomerID HAVING COUNT(*) > 5;"
,
"rows_read"
:
123
,
"rows_written"
:
4567
}
]
}
```

#### Path Parameters

The name of the organization or user.

The name of the database.

#### Response

The top queries performed on the given database as well as the total rows read and written.

Show child attributes

A string representing the SQL query executed.

An integer indicating the number of rows read by the query, which reflects the volume of data the query processed from the database.

An integer indicating the number of rows written (inserted, updated, or deleted) by the query, which reflects the impact of the query on the database data.

```
curl
-L
-X
GET
'https://api.turso.tech/v1/organizations/{organizationName}/databases/{databaseName}/stats'
\
-H
'Authorization: Bearer TOKEN'
```

```
{
"top_queries"
:
[
{
"query"
:
"SELECT COUNT(*), CustomerID FROM Orders GROUP BY CustomerID HAVING COUNT(*) > 5;"
,
"rows_read"
:
123
,
"rows_written"
:
4567
}
]
}
```

# Create API Token

Returns a new API token belonging to a user.

Bearer authentication header of the form `Bearer <token>` , where `<token>` is your auth token.

The name of the api token.

```
curl
-L
-X
POST https://api.turso.tech/v1/auth/api-tokens/
{
tokenName
}
\
-H
'Authorization: Bearer TOKEN'
```

```
{
"id"
:
"clGFZ4STEe6fljpFzIum8A"
,
"name"
:
"my-token"
,
"token"
:
"..."
}
```

The `token` in the response is never revealed again. Store this somewhere safe, and never share or commit it to source control.

#### Path Parameters

The name of the api token.

#### Response

The ID generated by Turso for the API Token.

The name given to the API Token.

The actual token contents as a JWT. This is used with the `Bearer` header, see[ Authentication ](https://docs.turso.tech/authentication)for more details. **This token is never revealed again.**

-L

{
tokenName

:

,

# Validate API Token

Validates an API token belonging to a user.

Bearer authentication header of the form `Bearer <token>` , where `<token>` is your auth token.

```
curl
-L
'https://api.turso.tech/v1/v1/auth/validate'
\
-H
'Authorization: Bearer TOKEN'
```

```
{
"exp"
:
999
}
```

#### Response

The time of expiration for the provided token in unix epoch seconds, or `-1` if there is no expiration.

curl
-L

# Welcome to Turso

Turso is a SQLite-compatible database built on[ libSQL ](https://docs.turso.tech/libsql), the Open Contribution fork of SQLite. It enables scaling to hundreds of thousands of databases per organization and supports replication to any location, including your own servers, for microsecond-latency access.

## ​New to Turso?

Start using Turso with your existing SQLite database, or create one with Turso.

## Quickstart

Get started with Turso to create and integrate your first database.

## ​Start building

Learn how to manage, distribute and integrate your databases with the CLI, API and SDKs.

## Turso CLI

Manage groups, databases, and API tokens with the Turso CLI.

## Turso Platform API

Manage groups, databases, and API tokens with the Turso API.

## SDKs

Integrate Turso into your application with one of our libSQL drivers.

## Tutorials

Learn how to work with Turso and your favorite language or framework.

## ​Join the community

Join the Turso community to ask questions, discuss best practices, and share tips.

## Discord

## GitHub

## Twitter / X

--request

organizationName
}
/invites
\
--header
'Content-Type: application/json'
\

  "role": "admin",
  "username": "<string>"
}'
```

:

,

:

,

1

If you want to invite someone who is already a registered Turso user, you can[ add them ](https://docs.turso.tech/api-reference/organizations/members/add)instead.

You must be an `owner` or `admin` to invite other users. **You can only invite users to a team and not your personal account.**

#### Body

The role given to the user.

The datetime the invite was deleted (or revoked) in[ ISO 8601 ](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_8601)format. Example: `2023-01-01T00:00:00Z` 

The unique ID for the invite.

The unique ID for the invite.

Returns the current status for blocked reads.

Returns the current status for blocked writes.

The name of the organization. Every user has a `personal` organization for their own account.

The organization slug. This will be your username for `personal` accounts.

The type of account this organization is. Will always be `personal` or `team` .

`personal`

`team`

The unique ID for the invite.

The unique ID for the invite.

`admin`

`member`

The unique token used to verify the invite.

The datetime the invite was updated in[ ISO 8601 ](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_8601)format. Example: `2023-01-01T00:00:00Z`

--request
POST
\

{
organizationName
}
/invites

# group locations list

You can obtain a list of all locations that a group belongs to by running the following command:

```
turso group locations list
<
group-name

https://docs.turso.tech//cli/group/token:
# group tokens create

You can create a new token that can be used to connect to any database in the group using the command:

```
turso group tokens create
<
group-name
>
[
flags
]
```

## ​Flags

| Flag | Description |
|---|---|
|  `-e` , `--expiration`  | The expiration time for a token, can be `never` or a value in days, e.g. `7d` . |
|  `-r` , `--read-only`  | Restrict the token to read only access. |


## ​Examples

The examples below outline the most common use cases for the `group tokens create` command.

### ​Create a token with read only access

You can create a token with read only access using the command:

```
turso group tokens create
<
group-name
>
--read-only
```

### ​Create a token with a specific expiration time

You can create a token with a specific expiration time using the command:

```
turso group tokens create
<
group-name
>
--expiration
7d
```

- [ Flags ](https://docs.turso.tech//cli/group/tokens/create/#flags)
- [ Examples ](https://docs.turso.tech//cli/group/tokens/create/#examples)
- [ Create a token with read only access ](https://docs.turso.tech//cli/group/tokens/create/#create-a-token-with-read-only-access)
- [ Create a token with a specific expiration time ](https://docs.turso.tech//cli/group/tokens/create/#create-a-token-with-a-specific-expiration-time)

# Welcome to Turso

Turso is a SQLite-compatible database built on[ libSQL ](https://docs.turso.tech/libsql), the Open Contribution fork of SQLite. It enables scaling to hundreds of thousands of databases per organization and supports replication to any location, including your own servers, for microsecond-latency access.

## ​New to Turso?

Start using Turso with your existing SQLite database, or create one with Turso.

## Quickstart

Get started with Turso to create and integrate your first database.

## ​Start building

Learn how to manage, distribute and integrate your databases with the CLI, API and SDKs.

## Turso CLI

Manage groups, databases, and API tokens with the Turso CLI.

## Turso Platform API

Manage groups, databases, and API tokens with the Turso API.

## SDKs

Integrate Turso into your application with one of our libSQL drivers.

## Tutorials

Learn how to work with Turso and your favorite language or framework.

## ​Join the community

Join the Turso community to ask questions, discuss best practices, and share tips.

https://docs.turso.tech//cli/db/tokens/i:
# db tokens invalidate

You can invalidate all tokens for a database by running the following command:

```
turso db tokens invalidate
<
database-name
>
[
flags
]
```

## ​Flags

| Flag | Description |
|---|---|
|  `-y` , `--yes`  | Confirms the invalidation of all existing db tokens. |


All tokens in the group that provided database belongs will also be invalidated. This means that all existing tokens will no longer be valid and will need to be regenerated.

- [ Flags ](https://docs.turso.tech//cli/db/tokens/invalidate/#flags)

https://docs.turso.tech//cli/org/members:
# org members list

To list all members of the current active organization, run the following command:

`turso org members list`

This command is only available to active organizations, use[ org switch ](https://docs.turso.tech/cli/org/switch)if you’re currently authenticated with your personal account.
https://docs.turso.tech//cli/plan/overag:
# plan overages disable

You can disable overages for the current repository by running the following command:

`turso plan overages disable`

Any overages that have already been incurred will still be charged.
https://docs.turso.tech//cli/org/members:
# org members invite

To invite someone who isn’t already a Turso user to the current active organization, run the following command:

```
turso org members invite
<
email
>
[
flags
]
```

## ​Flags

| Flag | Description |
|---|---|
|  `-a` , `--admin`  | Add the user as an admin. |


- [ Flags ](https://docs.turso.tech//cli/org/members/invite/#flags)

# org members add

To add an existing Turso user as a member to the current active organization, run the following command:

```
turso org members
add
<
username
>
[
flags
]
```

| Flag | Description |
|---|---|
|  `-a` , `--admin`  | Add the user as an admin. |

# Next.js + Turso

Set up Turso in your Next.js project in minutes.

Image: [ Next.js banner ](https://mintlify.s3-us-west-1.amazonaws.com/turso/images/guides/nextjs-banner.png)

## ​Prerequisites

Before you start, make sure you:

- [ Install the Turso CLI ](https://docs.turso.tech/cli/installation)
- [ Sign up or login to Turso ](https://docs.turso.tech/cli/authentication#signup)
- Have a Next.js app —[ learn more ](https://nextjs.org/docs/getting-started/installation)


Install the libSQL SDK

```
npm
install
@libsql/client
```

Configure database credentials

Get the database URL:

```
turso db show
--url
<
database-name
>
```

Get the database authentication token:

```
turso db tokens create
<
database-name
>
```

Assign credentials to the environment variables inside `.env.local` :

```
TURSO_DATABASE_URL
=
"..."
TURSO_AUTH_TOKEN
=
"..."
```

Configure LibSQL client

```
import
{
createClient
}
from
"@libsql/client"
;
// import { createClient } from "@libsql/client/web";
export
const
turso
=
createClient
(
{
url
:
process
.
env
.
TURSO_DATABASE_URL
!
,
authToken
:
process
.
env
.
TURSO_AUTH_TOKEN
,
}
)
;
```

Execute SQL

```
import
{  turso  }
from
"@/lib/turso"
;
export
default
async
function
Page
(
)
{
const
{
rows
}
=
await
turso
.
execute
(
"SELECT * FROM table_name"
)
;
return
(
< ul >

      
{
rows
.
map
(
(
row
)
=>
(
< li   key = { row . id } >
{
row
.
id
}
</ li >
)
)
}

    
</ ul >
)
;
}
```

Install Drizzle and the libSQL SDK

```
npm
i drizzle-orm @libsql/client
npm
i
-D
drizzle-kit
```

Configure database credentials

Get the database URL:

```
turso db show
--url
<
database-name
>
```

Get the database authentication token:

```
turso db tokens create
<
database-name
>
```

Assign credentials to the environment variables inside `.env.local` :

```
TURSO_DATABASE_URL
=
"..."
TURSO_AUTH_TOKEN
=
"..."
```

Create a Drizzle schema

```
import
{
sql
}
from
"drizzle-orm"
;
import
{
text
,
sqliteTable
}
from
"drizzle-orm/sqlite-core"
;
const
foo
=
sqliteTable
(
"foo"
,
{
bar
:
text
(
"bar"
)
.
notNull
(
)
.
default
(
"Hey!"
)
,
}
)
;
```

To learn about configuring Drizzle migrations, go to[ this
page ](https://orm.drizzle.team/kit-docs/overview#running-migrations).

Configure Drizzle to work with the LibSQL client

```
import
{
drizzle
}
from
"drizzle-orm/libsql"
;
import
{
createClient
}
from
"@libsql/client"
;
const
turso
=
createClient
(
{
url
:
process
.
env
.
TURSO_DATABASE_URL
!
,
authToken
:
process
.
env
.
TURSO_AUTH_TOKEN
,
}
)
;
export
const
db
=
drizzle
(
turso
)
;
```

Query your Turso database

```
import
{  db  }
from
"./db"
;
const
result
=
await
db
.
select
(
)
.
from
(
foo
)
.
all
(
)
;
```

Visualize Turso database with Drizzle Studio

To preview and manage database data with Drizzle Studio, prepare the Drizzle config file:

```
import
type
{
Config
}
from
"drizzle-kit"
;
import
*
as
dotenv
from
"dotenv"
;
dotenv
.
config
(
)
;
export
default
{
schema
:
"./drizzle/schema.ts"
,
out
:
"./drizzle/migrations"
,
driver
:
"turso"
,
dbCredentials
:
{
url
:
process
.
env
.
TURSO_DATABASE_URL
,
authToken
:
process
.
env
.
TURSO_AUTH_TOKEN
,
}
,
}
satisfies Config
;
```

Lauch Drizzle Studio.

`npx drizzle-kit studio`

https://docs.turso.tech//cli/authenticat:
# Authentication

## ​login

`login`

The Turso CLI uses an access token to authenticate with Turso. You can login using the command:

`turso auth login`

This will open a browser window, asking you to log into your account with GitHub.

If you’re using Windows with WSL or a remote CI/CD environment, pass the `--headless` flag.

Once you’re logged in, you can manage your account and databases. You can explore all of the commands via the docs, or by using the `--help` flag for each subcommand:

`turso`

The Turso CLI requires you to reauthenticate after one week. Don’t share your token.

## ​signup

`signup`

If you’re new to Turso, you can create an account using the Turso CLI:

`turso auth signup`

## ​whoami

`whoami`

You can get the username of the currently logged in user using the Turso CLI:

```
turso auth
whoami
```

## ​logout

`logout`

You can logout of the Turso CLI using the `logout` command:

```
turso auth
logout
```

## ​token

`token`

You can obtain the current access token used to authenticate Turso:

`turso auth token`

- [ logout ](https://docs.turso.tech//cli/authentication#signup/#logout)

# Welcome to Turso

Turso is a SQLite-compatible database built on[ libSQL ](https://docs.turso.tech/libsql), the Open Contribution fork of SQLite. It enables scaling to hundreds of thousands of databases per organization and supports replication to any location, including your own servers, for microsecond-latency access.

## ​New to Turso?

Start using Turso with your existing SQLite database, or create one with Turso.

## Quickstart

Get started with Turso to create and integrate your first database.

## ​Start building

Learn how to manage, distribute and integrate your databases with the CLI, API and SDKs.

## Turso CLI

Manage groups, databases, and API tokens with the Turso CLI.

## Turso Platform API

Manage groups, databases, and API tokens with the Turso API.

## SDKs

Integrate Turso into your application with one of our libSQL drivers.

## Tutorials

Learn how to work with Turso and your favorite language or framework.

## ​Join the community

Join the Turso community to ask questions, discuss best practices, and share tips.

# Add Member

Add an existing Turso user to an organization.

Bearer authentication header of the form `Bearer <token>` , where `<token>` is your auth token.

The name of the organization or user.

The role given to the user.

The username of an existing Turso user.

```
curl
--request
POST
\
--url
https://api.turso.tech/v1/organizations/
{
organizationName
}
/members
\
--header
'Content-Type: application/json'
\
--data
'{
  "role": "admin",
  "username": "<string>"
}'
```

```
{
"member"
:
"iku"
,
"role"
:
"owner"
}
```

If you want to add someone who is not a registered Turso user, you can[ create an invite ](https://docs.turso.tech/api-reference/organizations/invites/create)instead.

You must be an `owner` or `admin` to add other members. **You can only add users to a team and not your personal account.** 

#### Path Parameters

The name of the organization or user.

#### Body

The role given to the user.

`admin`

`member`

The username of an existing Turso user.

#### Response

The username for the member.

The role assigned to the member. Will be `owner` , `admin` or `member` .

`owner`

`admin`

`member`

Install the libSQL SDK

```
npm
install
@libsql/client
```

Configure database credentials

Get the database URL.

```
turso db show
--url
<
database-name
>
```

Get the database authentication token.

```
turso db tokens create
<
database-name
>
```

Assign credentials to the environment variables inside `.env` .

```
TURSO_DATABASE_URL
=
"..."
TURSO_AUTH_TOKEN
=
"..."
```

Configure LibSQL Client.

```
import
{
createClient
}
from
"@libsql/client/http"
;
import
{
AppLoadContext
}
from
"@remix-run/node"
;
interface
Env
{
TURSO_AUTH_TOKEN
?
:
string
;
TURSO_DATABASE_URL
?
:
string
;
}
export
const
turso
=
(
serverContext
:
AppLoadContext
)
=>
createClient
(
{
url
:
serverContext
.
env
.
TURSO_DATABASE_URL
,
authToken
:
serverContext
.
env
.
TURSO_AUTH_TOKEN
,
}
)
;
```

Execute SQL

```
import
type
{
LoaderArgs
,
LoaderFunction
}
from
"@remix-run/node"
;
import
{
buildDbClient
}
from
"~/lib/turso"
;
export
const
loader
:
LoaderFunction
=
async
(
{
context
}
:
LoaderArgs
)
=>
{
const
db
=
turso
(
context
)
;
const
{
rows
}
=
await
db
.
execute
(
"select * from table_name"
)
;
return
{
items
:
rows
,
}
;
}
;
```

# SvelteKit + Turso

Set up Turso in your SvelteKit project in minutes

Image: [ SvelteKit banner ](https://mintlify.s3-us-west-1.amazonaws.com/turso/images/guides/svelte-banner.png)

## ​Prerequisites

Before you start, make sure you:

- [ Install the Turso CLI ](https://docs.turso.tech/cli/installation)
- [ Sign up or login to Turso ](https://docs.turso.tech/cli/authentication#signup)
- Have a SvelteKit app —[ learn more ](https://kit.svelte.dev/docs/creating-a-project)


Install the libSQL SDK

```
npm
install
@libsql/client
```

Configure database credentials

Get the database URL.

```
turso db show
--url
<
database-name
>
```

Get the database authentication token.

```
turso db tokens create
<
database-name
>
```

Assign credentials to the environment variables inside `.env.local` .

```
VITE_TURSO_DATABASE_URL
=
"..."
VITE_TURSO_AUTH_TOKEN
=
"..."
```

Configure LibSQL Client.

```
import
{
createClient
}
from
"@libsql/client/web"
;
export
const
turso
=
createClient
(
{
url
:
process
.
env
.
TURSO_DATABASE_URL
!
,
authToken
:
process
.
env
.
TURSO_AUTH_TOKEN
,
}
)
;
```

Execute SQL

```
--
-
import
{
turso
}
from
'./turso'
const
{
rows
}
=
await
tursoClient
.
execute
(
'SELECT * FROM table_name'
)
--
-
```

# Quasar + Turso

Set up Turso in your Quasar project in minutes

Image: [ Quasar banner ](https://mintlify.s3-us-west-1.amazonaws.com/turso/images/guides/quasar-banner.png)

## ​Prerequisites

Before you start, make sure you:

- [ Install the Turso CLI ](https://docs.turso.tech/cli/installation)
- [ Sign up or login to Turso ](https://docs.turso.tech/cli/authentication#signup)
- Have a Quasar app —[ learn more ](https://quasar.dev/start/quick-start#step-1-create-a-project)


Install the libSQL SDK

```
npm
install
@libsql/client
```

Configure database credentials

Get the database URL.

```
turso db show
--url
<
database-name
>
```

Get the database authentication token.

```
turso db tokens create
<
database-name
>
```

Assign credentials to the environment variables inside `.env.local` .

```
VITE_TURSO_DATABASE_URL
=
"..."
VITE_TURSO_AUTH_TOKEN
=
"..."
```

Configure LibSQL Client

```
import
{ createClient }
from
'@libsql/client/web'
;
const
turso
=
createClient
(
{
url
:
import
.
meta
.
env
.
VITE_TURSO_URL
,
authToken
:
import
.
meta
.
env
.
VITE_TURSO_AUTH_TOKEN
,
}
)
;
}
```

Avoid a[ gotcha
moment ](https://github.com/quasarframework/quasar/discussions/16071)by
modifying the app configuration using the settings below.

```
{
build
:
{
target
:
{
browser
:
[
'es2020'
,
'edge88'
,
'firefox78'
,
'chrome87'
,
'safari13.1'
]
,
node
:
'node16'
}
,
extendViteConf
(
config
)
{
config
.
optimizeDeps
=
{
esbuildOptions
:
{
target
:
'es2020'
,
}
}
}
}
}
```

Fetch data from Turso.

```
import
{  ref  }
from
"vue"
;
const
items
=
ref
(
)
;
const
{
rows
}
=
await
turso
.
execute
(
"select * from my-table"
)
;
items
.
value
=
rows
;
```

# Welcome to Turso

Turso is a SQLite-compatible database built on[ libSQL ](https://docs.turso.tech/libsql), the Open Contribution fork of SQLite. It enables scaling to hundreds of thousands of databases per organization and supports replication to any location, including your own servers, for microsecond-latency access.

## ​New to Turso?

Start using Turso with your existing SQLite database, or create one with Turso.

## Quickstart

Get started with Turso to create and integrate your first database.

## ​Start building

Learn how to manage, distribute and integrate your databases with the CLI, API and SDKs.

## Turso CLI

Manage groups, databases, and API tokens with the Turso CLI.

## Turso Platform API

Manage groups, databases, and API tokens with the Turso API.

## SDKs

Integrate Turso into your application with one of our libSQL drivers.

## Tutorials

Learn how to work with Turso and your favorite language or framework.

## ​Join the community

Join the Turso community to ask questions, discuss best practices, and share tips.

## Discord

## GitHub

## Twitter / X

- [ Start building ](https://docs.turso.tech/https://nextjs.org/docs/getting-started/installation/#start-building)
- [ Join the community ](https://docs.turso.tech/https://nextjs.org/docs/getting-started/installation/#join-the-community)

https://docs.turso.tech//api-reference/o:
# Remove Member

Remove a user from the organization by username.

Bearer authentication header of the form `Bearer <token>` , where `<token>` is your auth token.

The name of the organization or user.

The username of a Turso user or organization member.

```
curl
-L
-X
DELETE https://api.turso.tech/v1/organizations/
{
organizationName
}
/members/
{
username
}
\
-H
'Authorization: Bearer TOKEN'
```

```
{
"member"
:
"iku"
}
```

#### Path Parameters

The name of the organization or user.

The username of a Turso user or organization member.

#### Response

The username for the member.

```
curl
-L
-X
DELETE https://api.turso.tech/v1/organizations/
{
organizationName
}
/members/
{
username
}
\
-H
'Authorization: Bearer TOKEN'
```

```
{
"member"
:
"iku"
}
```

# Welcome to Turso

Turso is a SQLite-compatible database built on[ libSQL ](https://docs.turso.tech/libsql), the Open Contribution fork of SQLite. It enables scaling to hundreds of thousands of databases per organization and supports replication to any location, including your own servers, for microsecond-latency access.

## ​New to Turso?

Start using Turso with your existing SQLite database, or create one with Turso.

## Quickstart

Get started with Turso to create and integrate your first database.

## ​Start building

Learn how to manage, distribute and integrate your databases with the CLI, API and SDKs.

## Turso CLI

Manage groups, databases, and API tokens with the Turso CLI.

## Turso Platform API

Manage groups, databases, and API tokens with the Turso API.

## SDKs

Integrate Turso into your application with one of our libSQL drivers.

## Tutorials

Learn how to work with Turso and your favorite language or framework.

## ​Join the community

Join the Turso community to ask questions, discuss best practices, and share tips.
